# What does fierce Hurricane Erin mean for the rest of the season?

## Hurricane Erin, the first of the Atlantic season, briefly reached Catagory 5 status. What does the intense storm mean for the rest of the 2025?

[Doyle Rice](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/2647905001/doyle-rice/) [Dinah Voyles Pulver](https://www.usatoday.com/staff/5222745002/dinah-voyles-pulver/)

USA TODAY

Hear this story

[Hurricane Erin, a major storm](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2025/08/19/hurricane-erin-live-updates/85719208007/) that is forecast to churn offshore of the East Coast of the United States for the next several days, briefly attained Category 5 status on Aug. 16 as it intensified in the Atlantic.

[Category 5 hurricanes](https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/nation/2022/05/19/hurricane-wind-speed-saffir-simpson-scale/9807231002/) are the rarest of storms, with only a small fraction of all tropical cyclo

search_results.title: What else is brewing outside of Hurricane Erin?
search_results.text:
Weather

# Ask the Meteorologist: What else is brewing outside of Hurricane Erin?

We're entering the peak of Atlantic hurricane season, and there are other systems to monitor for now.

Posted 2025-08-20T08:39:57+00:00 - Updated 2025-08-20T17:27:39+00:00

Ask the Meteorologist: What else is brewing other than Hurricane Erin?

By WRAL Meteorologist , Chris Michaels

Hurricane Erin, while not making landfall on the East Coast, is already causing issues.

[_RELATED: Erin causes rip current rescues, overwash while hundreds of miles offshore_](https://www.wral.com/story/tracking-tropical-storm-erin-august-2025/22114652/)

There are other storms in the Atlantic Basin that we haven't gotten to touch upon in detail to this point, so let's do that here.

## Two other waves to track in the Atlantic

Close to the Lesser Antilles, there is a system with a 60% chance of development within the next week.

South of Africa's Cape Verde Islands, there is a system with a 40% chance of development.

Key

# Tropical Storm Erin and Hurricane Erin – What We’re Seeing

August 20, 2025
• Expert Insights

### August 20, 2025

- **Dates Active:** August 11 to present
- **Peak Strength:** Category 2 Hurricane with 943 millibars
- **Maximum Sustained Winds:** 110 mph winds
- **Path:** Moving northward in the Western Atlantic Ocean
- **Significant Impact:** Expected to bring storm surge flooding and tropical storm conditions to North Carolina Outer Banks later Wednesday night, lasting through Thursday. Life-threatening surf and rip currents are also expected along the beaches of the Bahamas, U.S. east coast, Bermuda and Atlantic Canada over the next few days.

### August 19, 2025

- **Dates Active:** August 11 to present
- **Peak Strength:** Category 2 Hurricane with 961 millibars
- **Maximum Sustained Winds:** 105 mph winds
- **Path:** M

# Erin, the first hurricane of the Atlantic season 2025 forms, forecast to become a major storm
ByAuthor[Marko Korosec](https://www.severe-weather.eu/author/admin/)
Posted onPublished:16/08/2025
Categories[Global weather](https://www.severe-weather.eu/category/global-weather/)
**The North Atlantic has churned up the first hurricane of the 2025 hurricane season, Erin, which forms in the central tropics as it moves west. Over the weekend, Erin will continue to intensify as it approaches the Leeward Islands and Puerto Rico, becoming a powerful Atlantic storm. Latest model guidance suggests Erin will track between Bermuda and the U.S. East Coast next week.**
While tracking west, Hurricane Erin will move close enough to Puerto Rico to develop heavy rainfall, strong w

metadata.title: Will there be a stronger hurricane than Erin during the 2025 Atlantic hurricane season?
metadata.description:
In August 2025, [Hurricane Erin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurricane_Erin_\(2025\)) swept across the Atlantic Ocean and then moved through the northern Caribbean before skirting up the east coast of the United States and heading back out to sea. At its peak intensity, it reached 160 mph [maximum sustained wind](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Maximum_sustained_wind), classifying it as a Category 5: the highest category on the [Saffir–Simpson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Saffir%E2%80%93Simpson_scale) hurricane-intensity scale.

Still, it was no record-breaker. The most powerful Atlantic hurricane on record remains [Allen](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurricane_Allen), which in 1980 reached maximum sustained winds of 190 mph. And more recently, [Hurricane Milton](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hurricane_Milton) reached 180 mph in October 2024.

`{"format":"metac_reveal_and_close_in_period","info":{"post_id":39771,"question_id":39214}}`
metadata.resolution_criteria: This question will resolve as **Yes** if an Atlantic hurricane reaches maximum sustained winds of more than 160 mph before December 1, 2025.
metadata.fine_print: The primary source for this question will be the [US National Hurricane Center](https://www.nhc.noaa.gov/?atlc).
